Just a little chronology with help from Dr. Torigoye.  
Apparently the Ko-S=
hoami School developed out of the Katchushi tsubako 
in the late Muromachi =
Jidai.  After the hostilities ended with Edo 
Jidai emerging there was a di=
spersal of the Shoami School to different 
regions of Japan with the remain=
ing Kyoto artisans being the Kyo-
Shoami.  (Kyo-sukashi and Heianjo-sukashi=
 developed in Kyoto during 
Momoyama Jidai and into Edo until they more or =
less merged).  
Just a note -- the tsuba of Petter could also very well be =
Bizen Shoami 
as they had similar styles with the Kyo-Shoami in sukashi and=
 nunome.  
Dr. Torigoye mentioned the mimi thickness was a delineating poin=
t of 
reference, the Bizen being slightly thicker.  I am not certain if thi=
s 
style was used in the Ko-Shoami but a note of interest is that the gold =

nunome of the older pieces apparently was accomplished with greater 
skill=
 so that pieces of greater age often have more of the nunome left 
as oppos=
ed to the later Edo school pieces.
(OK -- did I get that right, Jim?)(BIG L=
OL)
